subject: Re: [junit] test generation as a tool for coverage
msgSnippet: ... The problem I have is in the word testing .  Having generated tests and achieve 100% statement coverage don t proof that you have tested what your
messageBody:
> Test generators are not really geared for functional *black* box
> testing, I agree, but they can be excellent for *white* box efforts.


The problem I have is in the word "testing". Having generated tests and
achieve 100% statement coverage don't proof that you have tested what
your application _must_ do. Even in a white box effort, you still have
to go through all your tests to validate them. Example:

/**
* @throws IllegalArgumentException if argument is null
*/
public void toto(Integer tata) {
if (tata == null)
throw new IllegalStateArgument();
...
}

you can achieve 100% coverage with a generated test, but this test will
not validate your program (because you don't throw the right exception).
You will then have to go through _all_ your tests to validate them.

Of course you will review every single test and you will end up with a
set of valid tests. But I doubt that everyone will be so careful. And
because all the tests pass, you don't know where to start (no error to
fix), so you'll take class number 1 and review the tests, class numer 2...

> This can help identify impossible paths in your
> code, as well as rare paths that lead to exceptions (such as null pointers).


I already thought of that and I think that a simple tool to discover
null pointers could be helpful. It can be a special TestCase of another
JUnit. But I don't think that if you generate "validation" tests for
JUnit, you should reuse these tests as the basis for your "unit" tests.

But I'm ready to be convinced

-Vladimir
